user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_count_sem_prop_t *count_prop)
{
    int                                 sval;
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_getvalue(&impl->id, &sval) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* put the info into the structure */
    count_prop->value = sval;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    int32     value;
} OS_count_sem_prop_t
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 21.17 concerns use of string handling functions from <string.h> (e.g. memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn). Neither the target function OS_CountSemGetInfo_Impl nor any of the provided related definitions invoke any of these string.h functions. The function only calls sem_getvalue and assigns an integer into count_prop->value. The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken perform pointer/index operations but do not perform any string operations. The count semaphore property struct contains a char name[] member, but that member is not accessed or modified in the shown code. Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided code that should be investigated for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. If string-handling operations occur elsewhere in the codebase (e.g. code that populates the name field or copies strings into other buffers), those locations would need review, but they are not present in the supplied snippets.
